expanded_description: Advanced applications of Newton's Second Law involving multiple objects, connected systems, and various force configurations

core_concept.explanation: When multiple objects move together or are connected, they share the same acceleration. The net force on the system equals the total mass times the common acceleration.

sections.section_title: Problem Set: Multiple Masses and Connected Systems
sections.introduction: These problems require you to identify the system, calculate net forces, and apply Newton's Second Law to find acceleration or individual forces within the system.

problems.title: Two Masses Pushed Together
problems.scenario: Two boxes are placed on a frictionless surface. Box A has a mass of 15 kg and Box B has a mass of 25 kg. They are in contact with each other. A horizontal force of 120 N is applied to Box A, pushing both boxes to the right.
problems.question:
a) What is the acceleration of the system?
b) What is the force that Box A exerts on Box B?

steps.description: Identify the system and total mass
steps.work: Total mass = m_A + m_B = 15 kg + 25 kg = 40 kg
steps.explanation: Both boxes move together with the same acceleration

steps.description: Calculate system acceleration using Fnet = ma
steps.work: a = Fnet / m_total = 120 N / 40 kg = 3.0 m/s²
steps.explanation: The net force on the system is the applied force since there's no friction

steps.description: Find force between boxes (analyze Box B separately)
steps.work: For Box B: F_AB = m_B × a = 25 kg × 3.0 m/s² = 75 N
steps.explanation: Box A must push Box B with enough force to accelerate it at 3.0 m/s²

solution.final_answer:
a) The acceleration is 3.0 m/s² to the right
b) Box A exerts a force of 75 N on Box B

problems.title: Three Blocks in Contact
problems.scenario: Three blocks with masses m₁ = 10 kg, m₂ = 20 kg, and m₃ = 30 kg are placed in contact on a frictionless horizontal surface. A force of 180 N is applied to m₁, pushing all three blocks to the right.
problems.question:
a) Find the acceleration of the system
b) Find the force that m₂ exerts on m₃
c) Find the force that m₁ exerts on m₂

steps.work: a = F / m_total = 180 N / 60 kg = 3.0 m/s²
F₂₃ = m₃ × a = 30 kg × 3.0 m/s² = 90 N

steps.description: Force on m₂ and m₃ together
steps.work: F₁₂ = (m₂ + m₃) × a = 50 kg × 3.0 m/s² = 150 N

solution.final_answer:
a) 3.0 m/s²
b) 90 N to the right
c) 150 N to the right

problems.title: Box Pulling Another Box - Horizontal
problems.scenario: A 50 kg box (Box A) is connected to a 30 kg box (Box B) by a light rope. A horizontal force of 240 N pulls Box A to the right across a frictionless surface.
problems.question:
a) What is the acceleration of both boxes?
b) What is the tension in the rope connecting them?

steps.description: Treat as a system to find acceleration
steps.work:
m_total = 50 + 30 = 80 kg
a = 240 N / 80 kg = 3.0 m/s²

steps.description: Analyze Box B to find tension
steps.work: For Box B: T = m_B × a = 30 kg × 3.0 m/s² = 90 N
steps.explanation: The tension must accelerate Box B at 3.0 m/s²

steps.work:
For Box A: F_pull - T = m_A × a
240 - T = 50 × 3.0
T = 90 N ✓

problems.title: Pushing from Behind
problems.scenario: Two crates are on a frictionless floor. Crate A (mass 40 kg) is in front, and Crate B (mass 60 kg) is behind it. A 200 N force pushes Crate B forward, causing both crates to accelerate together.
problems.question:
a) Find the acceleration of the system
b) What force does Crate B exert on Crate A?

steps.work: F_BA = m_A × a = 40 kg × 2.0 m/s² = 80 N
steps.explanation: Crate B pushes Crate A with this force

problems.title: Train Cars Coupling
problems.scenario: A locomotive (mass 5000 kg) is pulling two train cars. Car 1 has a mass of 3000 kg and Car 2 has a mass of 2000 kg. The locomotive engine provides a forward force of 20,000 N. Assume no friction.
problems.question:
a) What is the acceleration of the train?
b) What is the tension in the coupling between the locomotive and Car 1?
c) What is the tension in the coupling between Car 1 and Car 2?

steps.work:
T₁ must pull both cars:
T₁ = (m_car1 + m_car2) × a = 5000 kg × 2.0 m/s² = 10,000 N

T₂ must pull only Car 2:
T₂ = m_car2 × a = 2000 kg × 2.0 m/s² = 4,000 N

problems.title: Tug-of-War Between Boxes
problems.scenario: Two boxes are connected by a rope. Box A (25 kg) has a 100 N force pulling it to the right. Box B (35 kg) has a 70 N force pulling it to the left. The surface is frictionless.
problems.question:
a) What is the acceleration of the system and in which direction?
b) What is the tension in the rope?

steps.description: Find net force (take right as positive)
steps.work: Fnet = 100 N - 70 N = 30 N to the right

m_total = 25 + 35 = 60 kg
a = 30 N / 60 kg = 0.5 m/s² to the right

For Box B moving right at 0.5 m/s²:
T - 70 = 35 × 0.5
T = 17.5 + 70 = 87.5 N

solution.final_answer:
a) 0.5 m/s² to the right
b) Tension = 87.5 N

problems.title: Stacked Boxes with Applied Force
problems.scenario: Box B (15 kg) sits on top of Box A (35 kg). A horizontal force of 200 N is applied to Box A. The boxes move together without Box B sliding. Assume the floor is frictionless (but there is friction between the boxes).
problems.question:
a) What is the acceleration of the system?
b) What minimum friction force must act between the boxes to prevent Box B from sliding?

steps.work:
m_total = 35 + 15 = 50 kg
a = 200 N / 50 kg = 4.0 m/s²

Box B needs force to accelerate at 4.0 m/s²:
f = m_B × a = 15 kg × 4.0 m/s² = 60 N
steps.explanation: This friction from Box A accelerates Box B horizontally

solution.final_answer:
a) 4.0 m/s²
b) Minimum friction = 60 N

problems.title: Blocks on an Incline (Connected)
problems.scenario: Two blocks are connected by a light rope on a frictionless 30° incline. Block A (20 kg) is higher up the slope, and Block B (30 kg) is lower down. They are released from rest.
problems.question:
a) What is the acceleration of the system?
b) What is the tension in the rope?
(Use g = 10 m/s²)

steps.work:
Both blocks experience: F = mg sin(30°) = mg(0.5)
Total force down = (20 + 30) × 10 × 0.5 = 250 N
a = F / m_total = 250 N / 50 kg = 5.0 m/s² down the incline

For Block B: T - m_B g sin(30°) = m_B × a
T - 150 = 30 × 5
T = 300 N
steps.explanation: Wait, this seems wrong. Let me reconsider...

steps.work:
For Block B (going down): m_B g sin(30°) - T = m_B × a
150 - T = 30 × 5
T = 150 - 150 = 0 N
steps.explanation: Since both blocks have same acceleration naturally, no tension needed!

solution.final_answer:
a) 5.0 m/s² down the incline
b) Tension = 0 N (blocks accelerate naturally at the same rate)

problems.title: Atwood Machine - Unequal Masses
problems.scenario: Two masses are connected by a rope over a frictionless, massless pulley. Mass m₁ = 8 kg hangs on one side, and mass m₂ = 12 kg hangs on the other side. The system is released from rest. (Use g = 10 m/s²)
problems.question:
a) What is the acceleration of the system?
b) What is the tension in the rope?

steps.work:
m₂ is heavier, so it falls and m₁ rises
Fnet = m₂g - m₁g = (12)(10) - (8)(10) = 40 N

m_total = m₁ + m₂ = 20 kg
a = 40 N / 20 kg = 2.0 m/s²

T - m₁g = m₁a
T - 80 = 8 × 2
T = 96 N

m₂g - T = m₂a
120 - T = 12 × 2
T = 96 N ✓

solution.final_answer:
a) 2.0 m/s² (m₂ down, m₁ up)
b) Tension = 96 N

problems.title: Modified Atwood Machine
problems.scenario: Mass m₁ = 10 kg rests on a frictionless horizontal table. It is connected by a rope over a pulley to mass m₂ = 6 kg, which hangs vertically. When released, m₂ falls and m₁ slides horizontally. (Use g = 10 m/s²)
problems.question:
a) Find the acceleration of the system
b) Find the tension in the rope

steps.work:
Only m₂'s weight provides net force
Fnet = m₂g = 6 × 10 = 60 N

m_total = 10 + 6 = 16 kg
a = 60 N / 16 kg = 3.75 m/s²
For m₁: T = m₁a = 10 × 3.75 = 37.5 N

problems.title: Three Masses with Pulleys
problems.scenario: Mass m₁ = 4 kg and m₂ = 6 kg sit on a frictionless table, connected by a rope. Another rope connects m₂ over a pulley to hanging mass m₃ = 10 kg. When released, m₃ falls, pulling m₂ and m₁ across the table.
problems.question:
a) Find the acceleration of the system
b) Find the tension T₁ (between m₁ and m₂)
c) Find the tension T₂ (between m₂ and m₃)

steps.work:
Net force = m₃g = 100 N
m_total = 4 + 6 + 10 = 20 kg
a = 100 N / 20 kg = 5.0 m/s²
T₁ = m₁ × a = 4 × 5 = 20 N

solution.final_answer:
a) 5.0 m/s²
b) T₁ = 20 N
c) T₂ = 50 N

problems.title: Box on Moving Platform
problems.scenario: A 20 kg box sits on a 30 kg platform. A rope attached to the platform goes over a pulley and connects to a hanging 50 kg mass. The box and platform move together (no sliding). When released, what happens? (Use g = 10 m/s²)
problems.question:
a) Find the acceleration of the entire system
b) Find the normal force the platform exerts on the box
c) Find the tension in the rope

steps.work:
m_hanging (50 kg) > m_platform + m_box (50 kg)
Masses are equal! But hanging mass pulls down
Net force = m_hanging × g - (m_platform + m_box) × g = 0
steps.explanation: Wait - if platform goes up, box needs to go up too

steps.work:
Net force = m_hanging × g = 500 N down
This pulls platform UP
m_total = 20 + 30 + 50 = 100 kg
a = 500 N / 100 kg = 5.0 m/s²

steps.description: Normal force on box (box accelerates UP)
steps.work:
For box: N - m_box × g = m_box × a
N - 200 = 20 × 5
N = 300 N

Analyze hanging mass:
m_hanging × g - T = m_hanging × a
500 - T = 50 × 5
T = 250 N

solution.final_answer:
a) 5.0 m/s² upward (platform) / downward (hanging mass)
b) Normal force = 300 N
c) Tension = 250 N

summary: These problems demonstrate how to apply Newton's Second Law to systems of connected objects. Key strategies include: (1) treating connected objects as a single system to find acceleration, (2) analyzing individual objects to find internal forces like tension, (3) carefully considering the direction of forces and acceleration, and (4) using free body diagrams to visualize all forces acting on each object.
